name: Pesquisa de sites
description:
Na pesquisa sobre o nosso problema achei sites que contém fatos interessantes, como a percepção dos mergulhadores da lesão, partes do corpo afetadas por isso, algumas manobras que são feitas para tentar evitar a lesão, tratamento para o barotrauma, porcentagem de mergulhadores que já sofreram com isso.
Os sites falam que existem sete partes do corpo afetadas diretamente pela pressão externa, são elas: pulmão, ouvido médio, rosto com sangramento, dente, olho, gastrointestinal e no seio nasal e muitos cheguem aqui na terra com muito sangue na face pelo aperto da máscara de mergulho e o mesmo acontece com o barotrauma que afetada os olhos, seu motivo é pelo aperto do óculos de mergulho. 
O gráfico eu encontrei no site SOC, registrava que pouco mais de 80% dos mergulhadores já sofreram com a lesão. Outra curiosidade que eu me interessei bastante, foi as manobras que os profissionais de mergulho fazem para tentar evitar a lesão "barotrauma", algumas manobras são: valsalva para os mais experiente, frenzel para os iniciantes profissionais, além de outros como toynbee. Tratamentos para casos mais leves, analgésicos podem resolver o caso, mas em casos mais graves talvez será nescessário drenagens para poder fazer o tratamento.
Essas informações foram encontradas nos sites: Sensi Saúde, Manual MDS, SOC.

name: Research books
description:
During my research, I found 3 main books. They are:
- Freediving. From theory to practice
This manual is a constant reference tool for the activity of freediving in a safe and healthy way. Through simple and accessible language, the author, with extensive academic training and experience in the area of ​​swimming and diving, addresses topics of physics, physiology and pathophysiology of diving. With this book, you will learn how to dive well and be able to fully enjoy freediving in pools, lakes, seas or oceans using techniques.
- Diving Manual
This work is the result of many years of research on science applied to diving. In it, the author sought to conduct a bibliographic survey that shows the current position of scientific knowledge on exposure to hyperbaric environments, with proven facts, theories and the most plausible hypotheses for the various themes that permeate this activity. Discussing the main topics studied in the different diving courses available both inside and outside the country, this is the first Brazilian book to address the biggest change in the U.S. Navy tables in its almost 60 years of existence: revision 6.
- Scuba Diving - Essential Guides
Learn about diving equipment and techniques, from masks and fins to depth gauges and tanks. Explore the best diving spots in the world, from the coral reefs of the Pacific to the shipwrecks of the Red Sea. Make the most of your dives with a beginner's guide to marine life and ecosystems.

Another more relevant one is from Netflix and is called Breathtaking, it talks about freediving divers, and the challenges they face, and also has the situation of a diver reaching the surface out of breath.

name: About the project
description:
The problem occurs with divers, who when diving in the ocean, whether going up or down, experience a change in pressure that ends up harming them, causing barotrauma, which in this case would be a burst eardrum or even something more serious, such as sudden deafness.
1st: Barotrauma in the ear
Barotrauma is an injury caused by rapid changes in air pressure, such as during airplane flights and diving. Barotrauma can cause ear pain or damage the eardrum. The resulting pressure difference causes pain and, often, hearing loss and can injure the eardrum or cause it to rupture and bleed. When the pressure difference is too great, the oval window (the entrance from the middle ear to the inner ear) can also rupture, allowing fluid to escape from the inner ear into the middle ear.
2nd: Sudden Deafness
Sudden deafness is characterized as a sensorineural deafness that appears abruptly and has no known cause. Its onset is almost always unilateral, and is accompanied by tinnitus in approximately 80 percent of cases and dizziness in 30 percent. It only affects the ears, but is accompanied by symptoms of dizziness and tinnitus. Sudden deafness can be caused by several factors, but it is the most serious case related to barotrauma. The main problem of sudden deafness can be caused by circulatory problems, that is, the lack of oxygen circulation within the ear. The inner ear (the part that transforms sounds into electrical energy) only has a single blood vessel (internal auditory artery) for this blood to reach. Therefore, anything that causes this blood vessel to narrow can worsen blood circulation and reduce hearing. This hearing loss occurs quickly, that is, if a diver went diving today, later or the next day he will have lost his hearing completely.
3rd: Valsalva and Frenzel
The Valsalva Maneuver is a technique used to equalize the pressure in the ears during diving and avoid discomfort and injuries.
The Valsalva maneuver can be used to unclog the ears. When you are in the sea, you should cover your nose and mouth and try to exhale forcefully. The pressure in the ear canal should eliminate the air bubble that is blocking the water from coming out.
Recommendations:
Do not force the air out too much with your nose covered so as not to worsen the pain.
But when you are out of the sea, there are other Valsalva methods, such as:
• Yawning
• Chewing something
• Drinking liquids

The Frenzel Maneuver is an equalization technique used during diving, including spear fishing, to equalize the pressure in the ears. This technique is especially useful when the Valsalva maneuver is not effective or when precision and control of the equalization are necessary at more advanced depths.
It allows the diver to equalize the pressure in the ears with greater precision and control, making it especially useful in deeper dives or in situations where the pressure needs to be adjusted more delicately.
4th: Tympanometer
The test is performed by inserting a probe into the ear canal, which emits sounds and varies the air pressure in the canal. The results are recorded on a graph called a tympanogram, which allows the doctor to assess the health of the middle ear and identify possible hearing problems.

name: Problem, Barotrauma in the ear, Sudden Deafness, Maneuvers and the Tympanometer.
